div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Petition of FRANCIS STEPHEN MEDCRAF for Writ of Habeas Corpus. No. 3038
BRIEF OF RESPONDENT, STATE OF WASHINGTON ON MOTION TO QUASH WRIT.
div1.ab: Alfred H. Lundin, FRANK P. HELSELL, Attorneys for State of Washington
div1.p: Office and Post Office Address: 1116-24 Alaska Building, Seattle, King County, Washington.
IT IS WITHIN THE POLICE POWER OF A STATE TO FIX THE REQUIREMENTS OF THOSE SEEKNG TO PRACTICE DENTISTRY IN THE STATE.
Mr. Justice Gray, in the well know case of Leisy v. Hardin (1324 135 U.S. 127), in speaking of the exercise of the police power, said:

"It is that power which is characterized as that inherent power essential to the very existence of civil society, and the sageguard of the inhabitants of the state against disorder, disease, poverty and crime. "The power of a state to make reasonable provisions for determining the qualifications of those engaging in the practice of medicine and punishing those who attempt to engage therein in defiance of such statutory provisions is not open to question."
Justice Brown in Reetz v. Michigan, 188 U. S. 505, citing
Dent. v. W.Va., 129 U. S. 114-
Hawker v. N.Y.,170, U. S. 189.
To quote from the opinion in the latter case: g Hawks vs -

"No precise limits have been placed upon the police power of a state, and yet it is clear that legislation which simply defines the qualifications of one who attempts to practice medicine is a proper exercise of that power."

The issues raised in the case at bar are these: Do the statutes determining the qualification of those engaging in the practice of dentistry in this state create uniform and unreasonable classes? So these statutes fail to apply equally to all within the class created by them?
The State of Washington maintains:
1st. That the statutes in question are uniform as to all in like circumstances within the sphere of their operation.
2nd. That the classification is reasonable. Not such an arbitrary or hostile classification as infringes upon the quality guaranteed by the 14th Amendment of the Constitution of the United States.
The statutes fixing the requirements for the practice of dentistry in this state apply to:
"Any person or persons seeking to practice dentistry in the state, or to (own), operate or cause to be operated, etc., any dental office."
There is no restriction as to the operation,as the law applies equally to any and all persons.
The provision exempting persons engaged in the practice at the time of the passage of the act applies equally to all who at the time were practicing, and is reasonable.
State v. Powell (Minn.) 20 N.W., 238.
State v. Vanderlins, 42 Minn. 129. 43 N.W. 789.
Fox v. Terr. of Wash., 2 W.T., 297.
Webster v. State Board, (K.Y.) 113 W S, W. 415.
People v. Phippin, 70 Mich., 6. 37 N. W. 888.
Ex parte Spinney, 10 N.W. 323.
THE REQUIREMENT OF A DIPLOMA FROM A DENTAL COLLEGE IN GOOD STANDING IS A REASONABLE REQUIREMENT.

The petition well may state that: "The Supreme Court of the State of Washington has declared the said law herein quoted (R. & B.Code, 8416-24) to be not violative of the State or Federal Constitution." In the short but well reasoned opinion in "The Petition of E.G.Thompson for a Writ of Habeas Corpus", (36 W. 377), the following appears:

"If we are correct in our conclusion that the legislature, in the exercise of its police power, has authority, under the state and federal constitutions, to regulate the practice of dentistry within the state by reasonable rules, it follows that the legislature may provide that an applicant be possessed of a diploma from some dental college in good standing. There is nothing unreasonable in this requirement, nor in the other requirements named in the act. Such diploma is evidence of the ability of the applicant to practice dentistry. It is not conclusive of such ability, and the dental board may, therefore, provide reasonable rules for determining the actual ability of the applicant."

We submit that petitioner's position that "unless this court defends and preserves his rights under the Constitution of the United States, petitioner will be further restrained of his liberty, etc., pursuant to said void and unconstitutional law and in violation of the Constitution of the United States", 2
4. is untenable. The statement that the law is void and unconstitutionable is a mere conclusion. Petitioner speaks of his rights. What of the rights of the people of the State of Washington? Countless practitioners in the profession of dentistry have toiled through difficult and expensive college curricula in order to secure diplomas. Petitioner seeks to be given the same privileges without the attendant labor and expense.

The case of Webster v. State Bd. of Health of Kentucky (113 Sw., 415) is in point. That was a case in which mandamus was invoked to compel the State Board of Health to issue a certificate to practice medicine. The statutes of Kentucky authorized the Board of Health to admit an applicant to examination for a certificate to practice upon his presenting a diploma from a reputable medical college, or furnishing evidence that he was reputably and honorably engaged in the practice of medicine prior to February, 1884. The court denied the writ, holding that the requirement of a diploma was reasonable.

"The statute under consideration is a wise and beneficient exercise of the police power of the commonwealth, enacted for the purpose of protecting the people of the state from imposition by expirics and quacks."
We commend to the court's attention the case of State ex rel Crandall v. McIntosh (Mo.) 103 SW., 1078, as being almost identical with the case at bar.

Laws '05 Missouri declared that any person desiring to practice dentistry in the state, who shall have a license from the dental board of another state, or who should have received a diploma from a reputable dental college in any of the United States, should have the right to apply to the Missouri Dental Board for examination as to proficiency, and to be licensed and registered. In a hearing on return of a writ to mandamus, the court held: That a citizen of Missouri never having been licensed by any dental board nor having obtained a diploma from a dental college was not entitled to urge 3
5. that such section was unconstituional as impairing the rights of citizens of the different states and foreign countries because foreigners well equipped to practice dentistry in their country coming into Missouri without a diploma or license from a dental board or graduates of dental colleges in the District of Columbia and citizens of other States where no license was required, and who were not college graduates, were not entitled to examination in Missouri.
The Court in part said:

"A certificate from the faculty of a college attesting that its bearer as a student, day in and day out, with scholarly patience and research, had equipped himself with the technical knowledge taught in such college as contemplated by the foregoing statute, is of pronounced significance. It comes from the hands of honorable and competent men; it pledges the honor of the college that its holder attended lectures, possessed himself of the learning of his text books, passed his term and final examinations with credit under the eyes of his perceptors, and was capable of rendering professional services to the people in accordance with the rules of his art; that he was, in the language of State ex rel Gregory, supra, no pretender, 'no empiric, mountebank, charlatan, or quack'. It is manifest that no practicable examination by a dental board could go quite so deep or be so searchingly broad in its meaning as an honest,well - earned diploma of that sort. The law places its benediction on such a diploma, assigning it no trifling office, and public sentiment tends to support that theory."
See also People v. Griswold (N.Y.) 106, NE. 929.
Ex parte Whitley (Cal.) 77 Pac. 879.
Gothard v. People (Colo.) 74 Pac. 890.
Harding v. People (Colo.) 15 Pac. 727.

In the words of the court in State v. Creditor (44 Kan. 565, 21 Am. St. 306), 24 Pac 346 commenting on a statute providing that (1) it should be unlawful for any person to practice dentistry without having a diploma from a reputable medical college, and (2) exempting from the requirement of a diploma those engaged in the practice of dentistry or dental surgery within the state at the time of the passage of the act:

"if the regulations operate equally upon all who may desire to practice, and who possess the required qualifications, and if they are adapted to the legislative purpose of promoting the health and welfare of the people by excluding them from the practice those who are ignorant and incapable, then the fact that the conditions mau be rigorous, impolitic and unjust will not render the legislation in- 4
6. valid. The authorities uniformly support the exercise of this power by the state, and statutes simlilar to the one under consideration have been repeatedly sustained."
Citing: Dent v. W. Va., 129 U.S. 114.
State v. Vanderlins, 42 Minn., 129.
Hewitt v. Charier, 16 Pick 353.
Eastman v. State, 109 Ind., 278 (58 Am.Rep.400) 10 N.E. 97
Ex parte Spinney, 10 Nev. 323.
Harding v. People, 10 Col., 387. 15 Pac 727.
Musser v. Chase, 29 Ohio St. 577.
Thompson v. Hazen, 25 Me. 104.
State v. Gregory, 83 Mo. 123.
State v. Med. Ex. Bd., 32 Minn., 324. 20 N.W. 238

The New Hampshire cases State v. Hinman and State v. Pennoyer cited by petitioner are not in point and are no authority against the validity of our statutes. The New Hampshire statute,held to be invalid in the Hinman case, was an act regulating the practice of dentistry. It required a dentist practicing in one part of the state to undergo an examination and to pay a certain license fee, while dentists residing elsewhere in the state were exempted from these requirements. There was a discrimination between persons residing and practicing in the state, founded solely upon the accidental circumstance of residence, or a change of residence, and for that reason the statute was held to be unconstitutional and void.

Although not specifically declared in the act, the manifest purpose of the legislature was to exclude from a profession requiring learning, skill and experience those who are unfit to practice, and thus protect the public from ignorance and incompetency. No arbitrary or capricious conditions are imposed. The profession and practice are open to any and all persons who are qualified and can produce a diploma as evidence of such qualification. The legislature was fit to permit those practicing in the state when the act was passed and who are citizens of the state, to continue in practice without diploma or other evidence of competency. This fact is made by the legislature an evidence of skill and competency equivalent to a diploma from a dental college, and the wisdom of either test we submit, is a question for the legislature. The act cannot be held to unduly
7. discriminate between persons or classes and unconstitutional because it exempts those engaged in practice within the state when the law was enacted.
We ask that writ prayed for by the petitioner, Francis Stephen Medcraf, be denied.
Respectfully,
